abstract: State agencies, hospitals and social-service agencies continue to send homeless people to so-called three-quarter houses, poorly regulated flophouses that have been focus of New York Times investigation, three months after city created emergency task force to crack down on such homes; while illegal homes can be decrepit and dangerous, service they provide still fills need that is otherwise unmet as most homeless people prefer them to shelters.
lead_paragraph: The city formed a task force to crack down on so-called three-quarter houses, but none of them have been closed, despite evidence of continued exploitation and poor conditions.

headline.main: New York Faces Struggle in Curbing Flophouse Schemes That Victimize Addicts
headline.print_headline: City Faces Challenges in Curbing Schemes at Illegal Flophouses

snippet: The city formed a task force to crack down on so-called three-quarter houses, but none of them have been closed, despite evidence of continued exploitation and poor conditions.
